repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Economic Management Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Economic Management
            Technical Assistance Project for Bangladesh were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was low or negligible, Bank performance
            was unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Country systems need to be fully understood
            if they are to be incorporated into design. The team was
            aware that components will be subject to the Technical
            Project Proposal (TPP) approval process, and made
            suggestions as to how that process could be simplified. In
            the event, improvements were not taken up, and the slow
            working of TPPs was one of the main factors in
            unsatisfactory project performance. There are existing
            public administration constraints to how effectively a
            Government uses external Technical Assistance (TA).
            Bangladesh civil service's frequent rotation of staff
            undermines continuity of management, resulting in
            implementation delays. The practice of embedding project
            component management in existing agency structures is in
            principle sound, but in practice is undermined by
            counterpart staff holding several jobs at the same time,
            leading them to see project management as an extra
            responsibility. The procurement of consultant studies,
            training, and Information and Communication Technology (ICT)
            purchases should be routine functions of Government
            agencies, but were viewed additional burdens. Awareness of
            these constraints should inform the future design of
            projects. Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) systems need
            to be simple and meaningful. A diversified TA project with
            components of modest size and dependent on country systems
            for implementation can become unwieldy and beyond
            implementing agency capacity, if the Bank's standard
            approach to M&E is applied to each component.
            Furthermore, applying the Bank's results based approach
            to monitoring a project where the focus is on improving the
            machinery of government (as opposed to direct service
            delivery) is inherently difficult.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Economic Management Technical
            Assistance Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Management Technical
            Assistance Program (EMTAP) is an umbrella operation that
            aims to strengthen institutional capacities in core areas of
            economic and public management and contribute to better
            policy management and improved functioning in the public
            administration and corporate sector. The EMTAP consists of 6
            components, most with several subcomponents. Component 1
            strengthens Government capacities for better policy
            formulation and implementation, and improves the functioning
            of the civil service and public administration. Component 2
            modernizes revenue administration: Its 8 sub-components
            improve the National Board of Revenue's (NBR)
            organizational arrangements, and human resource management
            practices, undertake an assessment of the information
            technology needs of the revenue administration, improving
            customs valuation and assessment/clearance procedures and
            techniques of risk assessment, assess weaknesses and
            capacity development needs in priority areas, such as VAT
            (value added tax) business processes, strengthens the
            research and statistics wing of the NBR, strengthen training
            activities for revenue administration staff, and provide
            logistical support. Component 3 strengthens accounting and
            auditing practices in the corporate sector: Its 7
            sub-components prepare a Financial Reporting Act and design
            a Financial Reporting Council, establish and operationalize
            a Financial Reporting Council as an independent regulatory
            body; strengthen the capacities of the Institute o f
            Chartered Accountants of Bangladesh, the Institute of Cost
            and Management Accountants of Bangladesh, the Bangladesh
            Bank, the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the
            Department of Insurance; fund a comprehensive program of
            education and training; and provide logistical support for
            sub-project execution. Component 4 improves information and
            communication technology (ICT) use in the Government. Its 4
            sub-components prepare an e-Government strategy and road
            map/action plan for ICT development, establish an electronic
            communication network, train Government officials in ICT,
            and provide logistical support for sub-project management.
            Component 5 strengthens communication between Government and
            external stakeholders-with 5 sub-components which establish
            a Strategic Communications Unit (SCU), strengthen the
            National Institute of Mass Communications and provide
            training for Government officials, develop an E-network,
            enhance communication capacity in some important government
            offices, and fund additional activities. Component 6
            provides logistical and consultancy services for
            dissemination activities, procurement, and a post audit.
